posts.cooked:
Hi all,

My team is using mk4i swerve modules with NEOs for driving and steering. I explicitly set the rotation and sideways transition values to 0 in the drive method of my code to make sure I was only commanding the swerve modules to go either straight or back for debugging purposes. When I try going forward, the robot drifts and rotates a noticeable amount, and when going back and forth a bunch of times, the robot almost turns 60 degrees.

Video showing gyro plot: https://youtu.be/vZIdrbKYHIM

Video showing robot movement: https://youtu.be/cVLMU1bkP-0

Code: https://github.com/team2059/Max-Quordlepleen/blob/master/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/SwerveModule.java

I don’t think it has anything to do with Gyro drift because we are using a NavX 2, and it only drifts a degree/per minute, which is not nearly enough to cause the behavior shown in the videos I’ve linked above. I suspect it has something to do with the steer motors because they seem to be turning ever so slightly, and over time, it seems to be making the robot turn more and more, even though the steer motors shouldn’t even be active if the robot is only translating in the forward/backward direction. Maybe I’m missing something here, but any suggestions/feedback is greatly appreciated!

We had a similar problem a few days ago.   For us the issue was the measured velocity in our rear left swerve was never matching the commanded set velocity (and was nearly 0 all of the time).

We discovered this by connecting robot to advantage scope and looking at the swerve drive tab and seeing our “Measure” values didnt match the “Set Point” values for that module.

For us the issue ended up being bad encoder connection from the neo to spark max.

Few other things to check and confirm if you havent already.

Use rev hardware client and double check calibration zero point still look correct.  If one wheel is out of alignment you can see this sort of thing happen.

Use rev hardware client and double check calibration zero point still look correct.  If one wheel is out of alignment you can see this sort of thing happen.

Make sure your magnets are still loctited in place and havent drifted around.

Make sure your magnets are still loctited in place and havent drifted around.

Hope one of these helps and is easy fix for you!

I just checked the magnets, and they are in place.

I used Advantage Scope and noticed some stuff.

You can see the robot drifting to the left on the screen with advantage scope. It drifted 9.4 degrees in this video , according to the gyro. Why would the steer motors be moving slightly when I drive the robot on the ground vs over blocks? I’m still only commanding forward from the joystick with sideways and rotation being set to 0 in the code to make sure it’s not some deadband causing this.

You can see the robot drifting to the left on the screen with advantage scope. It drifted 9.4 degrees in this video , according to the gyro. Why would the steer motors be moving slightly when I drive the robot on the ground vs over blocks? I’m still only commanding forward from the joystick with sideways and rotation being set to 0 in the code to make sure it’s not some deadband causing this.

When I put the robot on blocks, the steer motors don’t seem to move at all. You can see that here . But when I drive it on the ground, the robot drifts, and the steer motors seem to actuate very slightly (moves 2-3 teeth in the gears), and you can see this causing drift in the video from my first point above.

When I put the robot on blocks, the steer motors don’t seem to move at all. You can see that here . But when I drive it on the ground, the robot drifts, and the steer motors seem to actuate very slightly (moves 2-3 teeth in the gears), and you can see this causing drift in the video from my first point above.

The weird thing is that the velocity vectors seem to be fighting each other in AdvantageScope, but in real life, the robot moves totally fine.

Just checking thru the code and gather more information (and not sure this will make any difference).

In Constants you have

and

Watching your video it looks like Units.inchesToMeters(24.5); is the X of your robot?  It looks longer then wide.    Translation2d take Translation2d(x, y) and it looks like you have Translation2d(y, x) relative to what you are calling robot X, Y.

I am not sure how the inverse kinematics work in the .ToSwerveModuleStates() so probably make no difference since it is some what arbitrary what you call front.

The wheelbase is longer than the track width in our robot. Also, I searched how other teams were making their SwerveDriveKinematics, and it is the same; they put trackwidth first and then wheelbase.

Any other suggestions ?

Here are the plots of the actual vs commanded steering set points:

Blue = actual current angle in rotations Yellow = commanded angular setpoint in rotations

Also, ignore what I said about the velocity vectors fighting each other earlier in the Swerve tab of advantage scope. I had to set rotation units to radians, lol. I had them set on degrees before. The only thing now is that it just seems that forward = backward, but at least the vectors all point in the same direction and don’t fight each other.

Noted…

we based our off the Rev Robotics template here:

which shows it as

Probably doesn’t matter as long as the values are correct and positions are correct and care thru the rest of the code (everyone you do fr, fl, rr, rl etc. which looked like you did).
Is it rotating the other way now? CCW vs CW?

I just changed the “forward tab” to down instead of up in AdvantageScope. The robot moves just as it does in real life now in the telemetry. I know this doesn’t really have anything to do with drift, but at least what I’m seeing on my computer matches what I’m seeing IRL. Still learning the ropes of AdvantageScope.

If I rotate CCW on my joystick, AdvantageScope shows the robot rotating CCW as well, and the robot moves CCW IRL. It’s the same thing for CW. Telemetry data is now good in AdvantageScope and matches my robot’s behavior. I still need to figure out the drift.

Sorry, I meant in your first video it looks like it is drifting CW

and in your most recent video it now looks like it is drifting CCW?

Oh, I see. That is an interesting observation. I didn’t really notice that until you pointed it out. Not sure why that would be. Regardless, the behavior still seems to be the same. Running out of ideas
do you happen to have a diff of everything that has changed since the first video?

You can see it in the GitHub. I’ve been going back and forth with 2 main things.

Using ChassisSpeeds.discretize(speeds, 0.02) in my drive() method.

Switching between

driveMotor.setVoltage(Swerve.driveFF.calculate(angularVelolictySetpoint))

and

driveMotor.set(optimizedDesiredState.speedMetersPerSecond / Swerve.maxSpeed);

I just tested out a few different combinations between using feedforward and discretize and without, and it seems to be kind of random. It seems to now just drift CW like in the first video, but then I’m Not sure how it drifted CCW in the most recent video I posted. I’m honestly just kind of lost and not really sure anymore lol. It’s drifting CW now with the same code that drifted CCW in the most recent video.

A while back you mentioned this:

mjjain:

When I put the robot on blocks, the steer motors don’t seem to move at all.

IMHO to me this makes me feel like it is something mechanical.

Possibly check the wheel diameters and make sure they are all the same and one hasn’t worn down.   A small difference might be accumulated over time to be a larger error.

Possibly check the wheel diameters and make sure they are all the same and one hasn’t worn down.   A small difference might be accumulated over time to be a larger error.

Also can try to intentionally fudge one of the zero offset just to see what that does.   How does it drive with one of those value being knowingly wrong by 3-5 degrees?  Does it do a similar thing where it drifts over time.   If so maybe recalibrate your zero offsets.

Also can try to intentionally fudge one of the zero offset just to see what that does.   How does it drive with one of those value being knowingly wrong by 3-5 degrees?  Does it do a similar thing where it drifts over time.   If so maybe recalibrate your zero offsets.

So for reference we are not currently using discretize().

but sounds like you have tried with and with out with no difference results.

Unfortunately we are doing our turning encoder in a very different way then you are, so hard for me to tell if there are errors in the logic of how you are doing it.

We have a duty cycle encoder like this

CTRE SRX MAG Encoder

Which we run directly in to the data port on top of the spark max.   We then tell the spark max to use that as its absolute encoder and ignore the hall effect encoder from the Neos which is kinda low resolution (42 counts per rotation).

the treads haven’t been replaced in a year, and they’re super worn down. Maybe that’s what is the problem?

the treads haven’t been replaced in a year, and they’re super worn down. Maybe that’s what is the problem?

still drifts even if I fudge one of them. I rechecked zeros and they seem to be fine.

still drifts even if I fudge one of them. I rechecked zeros and they seem to be fine.

I just tried it on really slow speed to see if the treads not getting enough grip on the surface was a problem. I tested driving only for like 10 seconds but it drifted 4.2 degrees. I’m honestly running out of ideas now lol.

These are what the plots look like using a feedforward to control the drive motors. Here’s what it looks like in my code:

In both cases, it seems that the actual velocity of each module overshoots by 0.4 m/s at the highs and lows. If this is causing the drift, why? Why would this cause the steering motors to actuate very subtly, even when I tell it to go straight? If this isn’t causing the drift, what could it be? Also, how would I mitigate this overshooting anyways, if it matters at all?
